It is characterized by its distinctive, slender, triangular-shaped phyllodes that give it its common name. The plant produces yellow flowers in globular heads, which are typically visited by a variety of pollinators. Acacia prismifolia is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it resilient in harsh environments. Its wood is hard and durable, historically used by indigenous communities for tool-making and construction.

It is found in the southern and western regions of the state, particularly in the areas of the Geraldton and Kalgoorlie regions.
